comments.commentBody:
"Has it ever occurred to you that not everyone who "wants" to be a doctor is capable of being a doctor?"

Having taught plenty of pre-meds in my life, I can assure you that there were some who I had nightmares concerning waking up on an operating table with them standing next to me. On the other hand, there were many who were perfectly capable of being doctors. If we simply let in half of all medical school applicants rather than 40%, the supply of doctors would increase by a quarter and wages would plummet.

"I suppose if some of those additional MD's were to become specialists, this might also drive down their prices, too"

The production of specialists is heavily gated by the medical school establishment in order to keep supply low and prices high. The "if" part of your hypothetical will not come true until the cartel is busted.

I hope michelle bachman becomes the next president of the united states. Its about time the white middle class who consistently flirt with the right wing in the republican party see what they are really made of. Let them decimate social security, medicare, medicaid, college aid, scientific reaearch grants, highway funds, libraries etc etc. lets see what is left of our great country when they are finished. I am convinced the white male who is the most likely to vote republican against his interest will be the most adversely affected by these policies. Maybe after all the devastation such leaders as Bachman will wrougt we will have a new beginning in this country. Witness your story about Floridas great republican governor.

No 5, it's you and the poor silly fools like you that are the trouble. Corporations saving Americans? Where do you live? Do you own a corporation yourself? Driving down the debt, created by two wars created by Bush? How will she do that, by printing more money? By selling the national parks? By offering to eliminate the money she gets for farm subsidies of her own property?

Bachman is a representation of everything scary about our present state of politics and the people who support her are even more terrifying.

"The Tea Party has got to be one of the saddest things I've seen in politics. To me it is nothing less than the cynical manipulation of the frightened and angry to mobilize and vote against their own interests."

Yeah, too bad that even the NYT wrote an article acknowledging that people who self-identified with the Tea Party are more educated than the populace as a whole.

So maybe you should find something else to be sad about. Might I suggest your own ignorance?

I am stunned by the responses from people outside of Illinois on this thread defending Blago. Clearly the media has not painted an accurate picture of this story, this man or his effect on our state. No matter any good he may have contributed (although I still can't get past the disastrous 'seniors ride free' CTA program), he  broke the law repeatedly, wasted Illinois' resources and abused his time as an elected public servant for the advancement of his own career. Illinois is in perilous financial state and Rod contributed to that. Claiming that he is a victim or that the corruption of others justifies his crimes is lunacy and just plain wrong.

I have lived in Barcelona, Valencia, and Alicante, Spain. I never had a Spanish driver's license and I learned to love public transportation in these cities. KMy wife and I used our car almost exclusively for trips to small towns outside Alicante. One thing that hasn't been pointed out in the article is that the density in many European cities is close to that of NY, making the metro/bus/train very cost effective since most people use public transport.

Still, living in sparsely populated NM, I commute to work 1hr and 15 minutes almost every day, driving a few minutes to and from the bus stop. On the bus, I work, read, socialize, and do crossword puzzles, and usually don't notice when we are in a traffic jam. I don't know how many accidents and traffic tickets I have avoided taking the bus. I have made a number of new friends on the bus and the price of gas is no longer a big issue to me since I only fill my tank every 3 weeks. Still use my car for an occasional trip or to drive to see family members on the weekend. Use of commuter buses here has increased tremendously, with large increases each time gas prices rise. I think we can make public transport work in the US.

This country really loves violence. Young kids can now learn how to kill for fun, feel no remorse so then they can join army and fight wars.
Unfortunately, they are not allowed to watch people making love on TV, peacefully smoke marijuana with friends or have a wine or beer with dinner.

An absolutely appalling example of journalistic malpractice, shot through with factual errors, out-of-date information and anonymous quotes from self-interested "sources" (a handful of incompetent EIA bureaucrats who have been embarrassed by their own utter failure to predict the shale gas revolution).

The absurd claims made in this article have already been publicly repudiated by IHS/CERA, the most reputable energy consulting firm in the U.S. and no prisoner of the oil and gas industry. Most other energy experts are scratching their heads in wonder at how the Times could possibly have allowed this article to get into print. It's that bad.

The Times should be ashamed of this grotesque and disgraceful lapse in its reporting and editing standards. Mr. Urbina fully deserves the scorn and censure he is currently receiving from legitimate energy experts in the U.S. and around the globe.
Good, bad or indifferent, this is called holding your representative (s) responsible. Kind of refreshing really.
We doubt that there are any, or were ever any, "mindless flaming idiots" representing Alabama in the House.

LarryG....you don't have a clue about what an exceptional job Rep. Woolsey has done for her/our district. There is a reason why she had been elected to so many different times to so many offices. Our country thrives in large part because of her good work and she commands a great deal of respect on both sides of the aisle. You are clearly misinformed about her and your rude remarks are a clear indication of this.

Seems to me the issue of the paucity of MD's to cover the HCR requirements was mentioned and discussed at length during the process of shoving it down the throats of able bodied citizens. So now it is imperative to survey? The horse is out..... close the barn door! If government would get out of the business of price fixing (illegal in any other business), the market would adjust to competition or perish. MD's who capitulate to government wage dictates choose to slowly perish, or choose not to participate and continue their profession. It isn't rocket science.

Oh, and Plus 6.....give credit where it is due, to the SEALs, the CIA, and other unnamed intelligence agencies, rather than to your hero, who is none of the above.
As one of her constituents, I can only say thank you for many, many years of sellf-sacrificing service to our community.

“ 'John Wayne [Gacy] was from Waterloo, Iowa,' Mrs. Bachmann told Carl Cameron of Fox News in an interview. 'That’s the kind of spirit that I have, too.' The actor [John Wayne] was actually born in Winterset, Iowa, which is about 150 miles southwest of Waterloo. It was John Wayne Gacy, known as the killer clown who raped and murdered 33 teenage boys in the 1970s, who lived in Waterloo. "

OK - is this just a normal slip?, or is MB communicating her inner candidate to us?

"It is the 'born-again' Christians that feel they must take back our country, and only they can do it, in the name of their religion. Romney has no such ambitions ..."

No, because the White House will be a de facto branch of the Tabernacle. Question the Elders and your soul may be impeached.

Silence is consent.
When a society permits something(such as minors purchasing and playing violent video games) it in effect gives its consent. This is the message that the court has sent today. Will teenagers see this decision as a victory for free speech, or will they see it as societal approval of violence?
The logic the court used today would indicate that the prohibition of the sale of pornographic material to minors would also have to be struck down.
I believe in the First Amendment, but the decision today indicates (a) a disconnect from reality (comparing Grimm's Fairy Tales to these video games?) and (b) a lack of common sense.
fcd

Our "budget" over the last 3 years has been $6.3 Trillion, yet Obama spent over $11 Trillion.

Now he wants the capability to spend more......as if we forgot the wasted $Trillion Stimulus that he demanded and postured about.

To Fresser, #2. Yes, that's what happened.

You often heard them say, "This is not about Democrats and Republicans."

Or, "Oh, don't worry, we're mad at George Bush too" when you reminded them that they were yelping about something (Wall Stree bail-outs) that started before Bush left office. Yet they resumed their "protest" without ever mentioning Bush's name or his role in the bail-outs.

I never saw a Tea Party picket sign with Bush's name or face on it. I never saw a Tea Party protest down in Dallas, where Mr. Bush resides. All I heard about Bush from Republicans was: "George Bush isn't the president anymore!"

Obama took the fire and Bush went skipping off with his loyal rear-guard action watching his back.
Jared Huffman will make a great replacement! Good riddance Lynn!

"...and perhaps even hire more, but when rates are low, they take them out and ... speculate! Len #7

I like your post, Len; however, while the middle tier "speculate", the upper echelon of the investment class either will take their tax savings and invest in solid 8% growth countries (i.e. maybe some "American" companies but definitely not the US) or develop instruments and market hype to Ponsi all the speculators. For some, risk has been completely removed from the equation.

Are there people who stand to make money from activity in shale and are spreading news in order to try and increase this activity? Are they making or influencing the news? It sounds like we are seeing the result of activities to inflate a bubble. This is what happens as the bubble inflates. To what extent the bubble is a valid bubble we do not know.

Those working to inflate the bubble do not care whether it is valid or not. Their only concern is to make it appear valid and a good investment. If there are assertions that make shale look dubious, they will try to see that these assertions are suppressed or overlooked or ignored or otherwise robbed of any power to make people take a second look. And if later the bubble is about to burst, they will unload their losses onto someone else.

The Times cannot report all this without evidence; all it can do is report the back-and-forth of the discussion and leave us to sort out the believable from the inflated.

Maybe I don't get it, but I just don't find it the least bit impressive to hide in a room and wast all your talents on destructive activities with no attempt to move humanity forward.  I call that a coward with insatiable appetite for attention.

Like Mouse (#13 above), I recommend Radio Wimbledon! (And Radio Roland Garros, for that matter.) You can listen on the Wimbledon website or on apps for the iPod or Droid. The coverage is fantastic; they frequently switch between courts if something interesting is happening. I think that Gigi Salmon's on air coverage of Isner vs. Mahut in 2010 will forever be my favorite moment (or favorite 11+ hours?) of sport commentating.

Also a plus is that it's nearly impossible to watch television at work without reprimand, but as long as I keep my cheering to a minimum, I can listen to the matches on the radio with headphones without drawing much attention to myself ...
This puzzle physicsly exhausted me.

As a physicist, I knew the speed of light and Avogadro's number immediately on sight. I love it when puzzles play to my strength. And Deb, the Avogadro's number in the clue is not a multiplication per se. It is scientific notation for a very large number - several significant digits together with a multiplier of a power of ten. The earth is 93 x 10^6 (93 million) miles from the sun, etc. 18 grams of water contain an Avogadro's number of molecules, almost a trillion trillion! This is a little over half a tablespoon. If you were to try and count the molecules one at a time and one per second, it would take you 190 trillion years! Or divide up the problem and let each of the earth's 6 billion people help you count and it would take the whole human race 30,000 years to count the molecules in half a tablespoon of water.

Rather than be afraid of numbers it is better to be in awe of them.
